_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Containment pad drains to process sewer.
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of an anhydrous ammonia storage in one ton cylinders interconnected with two reactors in one reaction building.  The storage cylinders store anhydrous ammonia as a liquefied gas.  The storage vessels utilize excess flow check valves and pressure relief valves a control devices.  The vessels are built to pressure code specifications.  A firewater system with hydrant monitors is available to use as a mitigation device for anhydrous ammonia vapors in the event of an air release.  The reactor vessels have relief valves, pressure and temperature control devices, manual shutoffs, check valves, alarms and procedures, rupture disks, purge system, scrubbers, emergency air supply, and a vapor combustor unit as control devices.  The plant personnel are trained annually in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, hazard communication training, and HAZWOPER training.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Mechanical Integrity program with valve replacements at regular intervals
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained HAZMAT Responders.  Firewater hydrants with monitors
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Replaced charge bomb with new charge bomb (CB3106); now includes it's own scale.  Reduction in personnel exposure.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: PSVs (PSV1351AY & PSV-1009), pumps P-1351/P-1351A, control valve PCV-1020
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of two ethylene oxide storage tanks that are interconnected with seven reaction vessels in a manufacturing building with interconnected piping.  The storage tanks are located within a concrete diked area complete with a firewater sprinkler system and a flammable vapor detection system.  The tanks are pressure vessels with a design working pressure of 75 PSIG.  The storage tanks utilize relief valves with rupture discs, freon refrigeration and a nitrogen gas (inert) blanketing system as control devices.  The storage tank area contains a firewater system supply controlled by a flammable vapor detection system.  The presence of flammable vapor causes the fire water sprinkler system to activate causing a water deluge to occur in the ethylene oxide storage tank area.   The reactor vessels have relief valves, pressure and temperature control systems, manual and automatic shutoff valves, check valves, alarms, rupture discs, a nitrogen gas purge system, emergency air supply, computer distributed control system, plus an instrument interlock system which will not allow ethylene oxide to be fed into a reactor vessel unless a number of process parameters are satisfied.  The plant personnel are trained annually in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, hazard communication training and HAZWOPER training.  All production tickets are reviewed by the engineering department after a production run has been completed.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained HAZMAT Responders.  Firewater hydrants with monitors.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Level indicator (LT-1300) and high level switch (LSH-1300)
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of an aqueous ammonia storage vessel interconnected with seven reactors in one reaction building and with four blend vessels in the blending building.  The storage vessel stores aqueous ammonia as a liquid.  The storage vessel utilizes relief valves as control device and is contained within a concrete diked area.  The storage vessel is built to pressure code specifications.  A firewater system with hydrant monitors is available to use as a mitigation device for ammonia vapors in the event of an air release.  The reactor vessels have relief valves, pressure and temperature control devices, manual shutoffs, check valves, alarms and procedures, rupture disks, purge system, scrubbers, emergency air supply, and a vapor combustor unit as control devices.  The blend vessel has a relief valve, manual shutoffs, check valves, procedures, purge system, an emergency air system, water scrubber and a vapor combustor as a control device.  The plant personnel have been trained in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, hazard communication training, and HAZWOPER training.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Mechanical Integrity inspection program with valve replacements at regular intervals.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained HAZMAT Responders.  Firewater hydrants with monitors.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: R304/305/Emergency shutdown in DCS to stop oxide charge.
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of two propylene oxide storage tanks that are interconnected with seven reaction vessels in a manufacturing building.  The storage tanks are located within a concrete diked area, complete with a firewater sprinkler system and flammable vapor detection system.  The storage tanks are pressure vessels with a design working pressure of 75 PSIG.  The storage tanks utilize relief valves with rupture discs, freon refrigeration, and a nitrogen gas (inert) blanketing system.  The storage tank area contains a firewater system supply controlled by a flammable vapor detection system.  The presence of flammable vapor causes the firewater sprinkler system to activate causing a water deluge to occur in the propylene oxide storage tank area.  The reactor vessels have relief valves, pressure and temperature control systems, manual and automatic shutoff valves, check valves, alarms, rupture discs, nitrogen gas purge, system emergency air supply, a computer distributed control system, plus an instrument interlock system which will not allow propylene oxide to be fed into a reactor vessel unless a number process parameters are satisfied.  The plant personnel are annually trained in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, and HAZWOPER training.  All production tickets are reviewed by the engineering department after a production run has been completed.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained HAZOP responders.  Firewater hydrants with monitors.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Tank level indicator, high level switch, temp indicator
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of the formaldehyde storage tank, seven reactor vessels in one manufacturing building, seven reactor vessels in another manufacturing building, and the interconnecting piping.  The formaldehyde is stored in two insulated heated above ground storage tanks.  The storage tank areblanketed with nitrogen gas and the nitrogen gas/formaldehyde vapors are vented to the plant vapor combustor system as a control device.  The tank is equipped with high liquid level shutoff protection and relief valve protection.  A firewater system with hydrant monitors is available for use in fire conditions.  Both fire fighting foam and spill control (vapor suppression) foam is maintained at the plant.  The reactor vessels in all three manufacturing buildings have relief valves, pressure and temperature control systems, manual and automatic shutoff valves, check valves, alarms, rupture discs, nitrogen purge systems, a vapor combustor for vapor destruction, emergency air supply, a computer distributed control system for batch reaction control in the two buildings and PLC control in the third building.  The plant personnel are annually trained in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, hazard communication training, and HAZWOPER training.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained HAZMAT Responders.  Firewater hydrants with monitors.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Weekly AVO/SPCC inspection of piping, tanks, units
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of ethylenediamine that is stored in drums, two reactor vessels in one manufacturing building, two additional vessels in the other manufacturing building, and the interconnecting piping.  Ethylenediamine is stored in drums on a concrete surface, with drainage that flows to the process sewer (can be contained) in the event of a spill.  The drums are brought to the manufacturing building on an as needed basis.  A firewater system with hydrant monitors is available for use in fire conditions.  Both fire fighting foam and spill control (vapor suppression) foam is maintained at the plant.  The reactor vessels in the manufacturing building have relief valves, pressure and temperature control systems, manual and automatic shutoff valves, check valves, alarms, rupture discs, nitrogen purge systems, a vapor combustor for vapor destruction, emergency air supply, and a computer distributed control system for batch reaction control.  The plant personnel are annually trained in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, hazard communication training, and HAZWOPER training.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Trained HAZMAT Responders.  Firewater hydrants with monitors.
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of methyl chloride storage cylinders, three reactor vessels in one manufacturing building, and the interconnecting piping.  Methyl Chloride is stored as a pressurized liquid.  The storage cylinders utilize excess flow check valves and pressure relief valves as control devices.  The storage cylinders are inspected and maintained to code specifications.  A firewater system with hydrant monitors is available for use as a mitigation device for methyl chloride vapors in the event of an air release.  The reactor vessels in the manufacturing building have relief valves, pressure and temperature control systems, manual and automatic shutoff valves, check valves, alarms, rupture discs, nitrogen purge systems, a vapor combustor for vapor destruction, emergency air supply, and a computer distributed control system for batch reaction control.  The plant personnel are annually trained in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, hazard communication training, and HAZWOPER training.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: extermal events, maintenance, sampling, routine shut down, routine start up
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Drains to process water sump for containment
_prev_prog_3.Description: This process consists of cyclohexylamine that is stored in drums and totes, five blend vessels in one manufacturing building, and the interconnecting piping.  Cyclohexylamine is stored in drums and totes on a concrete surface, with drainage that flows to the process sewer (can be contained) in the event of a spill.  The drums and totes are brought to the manufacturing building on an as needed basis.  A firewater system with hydrant monitors is available for use in fire conditions.  Both fire fighting foam and spill control (vapor suppression) foam is maintained at the plant.  The reactor vessels in the manufacturing building have relief valves, pressure and temperature control systems, manual and automatic shutoff valves, check valves, alarms, rupture discs, nitrogen purge systems, a water scrubber a vapor combustor for vapor destruction and emergency air supply.  The plant personnel are annually trained in emergency response procedures including fire brigade training, hazard communication training, and HAZWOPER training.

_accidents.CF_Other: Manufacturer supplied valve was not assembled correctly

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Baker Petrolite LLC is committed to operating the Bayport Manufacturing Facility and all associated processes in a safe manner for protection of the environment, the public population, and its' employees.  Baker Petrolite LLC has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at the Bayport Facility as part of this commitment. One part of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at the Bayport Facility and also complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) regulation 40 CFR part 68, "Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (RMP rule).  A requirement of the RMP rule is to submit a risk management plan (RMPlan) describing the risk management prepared for the Baker Petrolite Bayport Facility.  The purpose of this document is to satisfy the RMP plan requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at the Bayport Facility.



Through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances, Baker Petrolite is committed to the safety of its' employees, the public population, and the preservation of the environment.  Baker Petrolite implements reasonable controls to prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances.  In the event of a significant accidental release, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. If a release event occurred, Baker Petrolite would evaluate the release, evacuate workers as required, contact the LaPorte police department (LEPC) dispatcher to inform them of the release, and mitigate or eliminate the consequences of the release.  Baker Petrolite has established a program with the LaPorte Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), LaPorte Fire Department, and the Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) to warn the community if a release occurs that could affect the community.



Baker Petrolite is a specialty chemical manufacturer of chemical product

s for use in oil field production, refinery processes, and as additives for various end uses.   With the production of many types of chemical products, Baker Petrolite uses eight (8) chemicals which are above the RMP threshold quantities. They include anhydrous ammonia, aqueous ammonia, ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, formaldehyde, ethylenediamine, methyl chloride and cyclohexylamine. All of the covered processes involving these chemicals are Program 3 processes for RMP rule compliance purposes. The following is a summary of the individual chemicals and the covered processes:



1. Anhydrous ammonia is stored in cylinders (1,754 lbs each) and is used as a neutralization chemical agent in the production of chemical intermediates.



2. Aqueous ammonia is stored in a pressure vessel type storage tank within dike containment. Aqueous ammonia is used as a neutralization chemical agent in the production of chemical intermediates. 



3. Ethylene oxide is stored in two pressure vessel type storage tanks, each with individual dike containment. Ethylene oxide is used in the ethoxylation of chemical intermediates. 



4. Propylene oxide is stored in two pressure vessel type storage tanks, each with individual dike containment. Propylene oxide is used in the propyloxylation of chemical intermediates. 



5. Formaldehyde is stored in an aboveground vertical fixed roof storage tank. Formaldehyde is used in the production of chemical resin type intermediates. 



6. Ethylenediamine is stored in an aboveground vertical fixed roof storage tank. Ethylenediamine is used in the production of chemical intermediates.



7. Methyl Chloride is stored in cylinders (830 lbs). Methyl chloride is used in the production of quaternary ammonium chemical intermediates.



8. Cyclohexylamine is stored in drums and totes.  Cyclohexylamine is used in the production of blends. 



Baker Petrolite has performed an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) to estimate the potential for an accidental release

of a regulated substance to affect the public or the environment. The OCA consists of evaluating both worst-case scenarios (WCS) and alternative case scenarios (ACS).  Baker Petrolite does not expect a WCS to ever occur, however an ACS is a more realistic scenario that is more likely to occur.  The ACSs will help the LEPC to improve the community emergency response plan.  If you are interested in this information, please contact our RMP coordinator at (281) 291-3260.



The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Bayport Facility.  The processes at the Bayport Facility are not only regulated by the EPA RMP regulation, but are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) standard.  This summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.



The Bayport Facility encourages plant employees to participate in all areas of process safety management and accident prevention.  Employee participation ranges from updating technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. The employees have access to all information contained in the Baker Petrolite plant accident prevention program. One of the ways process safety and employee safety issues are addressed is in the monthly plant safety committee meetings. The committee consists of plant operators and management personnel.



Baker Petrolite keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of processes.  Chemical specific information is provided in safety data sheets (SDS). The SDSs are maintained and located online and can be access through the Baker Hughes Intranet. Block diagrams on PSM covered processes are included in the Bayport PSM Manual along with maximum intended inventories of PSM covered chemicals. Additionally, safe designed upper a

nd lower limits of pressure, flow, composition, and temperature for PSM covered processes are included in the Bayport PSM manual. The Bayport facility ensures the processes are maintained within these limits by using process controls and monitoring equipment, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems. An evaluation of consequences of deviation is included in the Bayport PSM Manual. The following information is maintained by the plant engineering department: materials of construction, piping and instrument diagrams, electrical classifications, relief valve design, ventilation system design, design codes and engineering standards employed in the plant, and safety system interlocks/suppression systems. A program is in place for all process equipment to comply with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.



Baker Petrolite has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with various processes. Each process is systematically examined to identify process hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. Baker Petrolite uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis method to perform these systematic reviews. The HAZOP team consists of people who have operating, maintenance, and engineering expertise. The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the processes as well as accident prevention and makes suggestions for additional measures as needed. The team findings are then documented and all approved changes are implemented for corrective action. These periodic reviews are conducted on a 5 year cycle and will continue until the covered process is no longer operating. Again, the team findings are documented and retained.



Baker Petrolite LLC maintains written procedures for the manufacture of specialty chemicals. Each specialty chemical requires a specific "batch ticket" for the manufacture of that chemical, intermediate or finished product. These "batch tickets" contain specific inform

ation on; raw materials required, quantities of raw materials, reaction conditions, and any chemical specific conditions for that chemical reaction. In addition to the "batch tickets", there are written plant standard operating procedures (SOP) which cover activities that are general in nature to a large number of common tasks. These SOPs cover general tasks such as; forklift operations, chemical storage tank filling, container storage, sampling procedures, housekeeping, and other activities common to many of the specialty chemical processes. Emergency shutdown instructions are contained in the Bayport Production Standard Operating Procedure Manual (P-26, P-27 and P-28). The "batch tickets" are reviewed after each batch to ensure they reflect current operating practices.



Baker Petrolite LLC has a company training program for all plant operations employees. New employees receive basic orientation training in plant operations regardless of their previous experience level. After successfully completing this training, the new operator is then assigned to a more experienced operator with job experience to perform the duties and tasks in the new job assignment. After the new operator can demonstrate the ability and knowledge (through oral and written testing) to perform the job in a safe manner on his own, he will begin to work alone. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training.



Baker Petrolite LLC uses a contractor who specializes in contract maintenance and other outside contractors for construction activities as required. Because the contractors work on or near process equipment, there are procedures in place to ensure that contractors; perform their work safety, have sufficient knowledge and skills, are aware of the hazards in their work area, understand emergency procedures, follow site specific safety rules, and inform Baker Petrolite personnel of any hazards they find in the area. Baker Petrolite LLC has written procedures both for the

contract maintenance contractor and the other contractors performing construction projects. The contractor maintenance contractor employees must attend orientation sessions for plant specific procedures, chemicals used in the plant, and Baker Petrolite LLC policies. There is a separate procedure (HSE-046) for construction contractors which covers plant procedures, safety rules, and emergency procedures pertaining to their work. In addition, Baker Petrolite LLC evaluates prospective contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. 



Baker Petrolite LLC conducts Pre-Startup Safety Reviews for a new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. This review provides an additional check to ensure construction is in accordance with design specifications to maintain process safety.

Baker Petrolite LLC has practices and procedures to maintain mechanical integrity of the process equipment at the Bayport facility. These procedures for inspections and maintenance are found in the several of the Bayport SOP manuals, namely; Maintenance SOP manual, Safety and Environmental SOP manual, and the Bayport Production SOP manual. Records for equipment inspections and testing are maintained by the Maintenance Department Supervisor. "Safety Priority" work orders are issued to correct problems or process defects.



Baker Petrolite LLC uses the following safe work practices to ensure worker and process safety: control of entry/presence/exit of support personnel, lock-out/tag-out procedures, procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials from process piping or equipment, hot work permit system, and confined space entry program. These procedures form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



Baker Petrolite LLC has a management of change (MOC) plan (Admin-102)  for handling changes to chemical processes in the plant. This system is described in the Bayport Sa

fety and Environmental and SOP manual. The approved MOC files are maintained in the plant engineering department. The MOC changes are communicated to the process operators on the production "batch tickets". Baker Petrolite LLC provides training for the plant employees involved in processes where significant process hazards exist.



The chemical processes at the Bayport Facility have hazards that must be controlled to maintain safe operation. The prevention program previously summarized applies to all the Program 3 EPA RMP covered processes at the Bayport plant. These prevention program procedures help to prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by human or equipment failures. Baker Petrolite LLC has safety equipment and features on all units to help contain or control a release and reduce the consequences of a release. The types of safety features used on various chemical process equipment for release detection are: hydrocarbon detectors with alarms, process alarms, and video monitors. The types of equipment features used for containment or control of releases are: process relief valves, tank scrubbers to control vessel or storage tank emissions, valves to permit isolation of process equipment, automated shutdown systems (high level, high temperature, no agitation) for specific process parameters, dike walls, backup electrical power generator for certain critical equipment, and backup firewater pumps. Baker Petrolite LLC uses the following types of equipment for release mitigation: Fire suppression and extinguishing systems, firewater deluge system for specific processes, trained emergency response personnel, and personal protective equipment.

Baker Petrolite LLC investigates all incidents that result in or could have resulted in a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, personal injury, or environmental loss. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the in

cident. Corrective actions are taken in response to the team's findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for 5 years.



To help ensure that an accident prevention program is functioning properly, Baker Petrolite LLC periodically conducts program audits. Safety audits are conducted every three years by the Baker Petrolite Corporate Industrial Health, Environmental, and Safety (HS&E) department. Corrective actions are taken in response to the audit team's findings.



One release of the eight RMP covered chemicals at the Baker Petrolite Bayport facility has occurred in the last 5 years and had resulted in an on-site shelter in place.  No off-site impacts resulted from this release.  The incident involved Ethylene Oxide and occurred on September 18, 2018 and lasted approximately 40 minutes from leak discovery (shelter in place iniated) to all clear sounded.   During the incident, approximately 1 lb of material was lossed.  An operator identified a leaking valve on the bottom of Tank 351 while lining up rail cars to off load ethylene oxide.  The employee notified the Shift Foreman and management, who decided to sound the shelter in place.  The deluge system was set off as a precautionary measure to prohibit off-site impacts. Consequently, there were no on-site or off-site impacts that resulted from this release.  During the investigation, it was discovered that a valve that was supplied by the manufacturer was not properly put together.  All of the remaining valves on the system were subsequently inspected to ensure the incident would not happen again.  



Baker Petrolite LLC maintains a written emergency response program for the protection of the plant employees, the public, and the environment. This program consists of procedures for responding to all types of releases including flammable and toxic chemicals. The emergency response plan covers all aspects including first aid, medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans, accounting for personnel aft

er an evacuation, notification of local emergency response organizations, and the public in the event of a significant release. There are procedures for maintenance, inspection, testing, and use of emergency response equipment. Plant employees receive annual training in these procedures to maintain their specific emergency response duties. The program is updated when necessary, based on personnel changes and plant process changes. The overall emergency response program is coordinated with the LaPorte LEPC. Baker Petrolite LLC has 24-hour communications capability with appropriate LEPC and CIMA emergency response organizations. This also provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response. In addition to regular meetings (LEPC and CIMA), Baker Petrolite LLC conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the emergency response organizations.



Baker Petrolite LLC constantly strives to improve the safety of the plant processes through periodic safety reviews, incident investigations, and by soliciting safety suggestions from the plant employees. The following  types of changes are planned during the next 5 years: installation of an additional steam whistle on the property to aid in easier communication of a significant event, LEL meters in the main sump that tie in to the DCS to automatically close the discharge valves in case of abnormal LEL levels and continued review and updating of personnel training and written operating procedures.
